author: Salmontheman

text:
My dear friend Sam, it looks like your entire life, you've always been with mind-driven and conditioned people who keep telling us that you need to achieve something and strive for becoming someone in order to be respected and have a happy life, as they do to all of us. You say, "I can change the world and as I'm striving to change the world, I will be happy". That reminded me the quote from Rumi which says;

"Yesterday I was clever, so I wanted to change the world. Today I am wise, so I am changing myself."

I'd wish you had known that you are already complete. You have already arrived. You are there. You didn't need to "become" anyone other than who you already are in order to be happy. Deep inside we are all one, regardless of our looks, what we do, have or achieve. We are like the waves in the ocean and no wave can be judged by being high or low, they are just whatever they are, and they just enjoy being without comparing themselves with other waves. 

I'm glad to know a beautiful and inspiring human being like you but I hope you had discovered the depths of your own being which is always there regardless of what you do and this world is nothing more than a play...

"I have lived on the lip of insanity, wanting to know reasons, knocking on a door. 
It opens.
I‚Äôve been knocking from the inside!"

Rest in Peace my friend...

text: The biggest problem for all of us is that we're thinking that we have time. If you look at this lad in the video you'll see that he had little time to unfold his dreams. So, at this moment he is dead and he'll never become an engineer or biologist as he wanted, but he use to live in his unique rhythm wisely. Thanks to this fact he succeeded in one dream at least, and if every single one of you ever could have an opportunity to ask him about his regrets and choices then he would confirm to you that he is still happy about all things in his life and time that he had with his family. We may not be people with limited capabilities or sick ones but we can die at every moment, and every single day in our life could be the last one. His example has to be a reminder to us all that we have to stop wasting our lives on meaningless things or conflicting with each other because all this stuff makes us unhappy and that's why every one of us has to start to seek ourselves in this world in order to live a happy life until it's not too late. And when you do this, it will be the greatest honour not only to Sam Burns or your own families but to all of humanity.

text: I was an Engineering undergraduate but I realized teaching is what I want to do. I am still one diploma away from the career yet the education diploma doesn't consider my UG degree as a relative subject for the subjects I want to teach(Math and General Studies). Some universities don't even open the course for primary...After looking at the computer for hours for 5 universities, I felt like the world doesn't want me to be a teacher. Just feeling depressed and struggled if I should keep this up since this is the second year of my applications. Yet I am still going to apply all the course to try my luck. text:
9:00 so sad to hear he passed away shortly after... He would have made a motivated researcher in Biomedical field! His story is really motivating for me to try and push the limits of healthcare. With biotechnology evolving and bringing us the options for genetic engineering, with CRIPR/Cas9, I think there's a good chance to potentially eradicate genetic diseases such as progeria. As progeria is very rare, the research I'm doing also digs deeper into a
 rather rare disorder, called PSC (primary sclerosing cholangitis). Another good thing is that some pharma/biotech companies are also shifting efforts to target smaller patient groups, even though they aren't so interesting from a business perspective, the latter which is a really sad fact. We need to keep doing research and development, both academic and industrial, to help those smaller patient groups that need us. And we should do it with the patients in mind, not with our own ego's and desires to build a 'publication' list. Something has to change in terms of funding and peer review systems and publish/perish, so that researchers can do what they are meant to do: find new ways to help patients!

text: share if you can. i feel like this young man can change many other young men's outlooks on life today. a lot of our youth are stuck on 'unhappy' and 'impossible' and 'life sucks' or 'life is boring'. yet, here is a young man that by all means should be able to claim a 'woe is me' attitude, and yet, the most important thing he wanted us to know is that he is living a very happy life, is looking forward to tomorrow, and is finding happiness even within the limitations imposed upon him by this disease. i'm so proud of him, of his family for raising such a positive young man, of his friends, of his band members, of his mentors... mashaAllah

text:
Crusade Prayer (94)
To cure the mind, body and soul
O dear Jesus, I lay myself before You, weary, 
sick, in pain and with a longing to hear Your 
Voice. Let me be touched by Your Divine 
Presence, so that I will be flooded by Your 
Divine Light through my mind, body and soul.
I trust in Your Mercy. I surrender my pain and 
suffering completely before You and I ask that 
You give me the grace to trust in You, so that 
You can cure me of this pain and darkness, so 
that I can become whole again and, so that I 
can follow the Path of Truth and allow You to 
lead me to life in the New Paradise. Amen.
author: Tool of GOD

text:
Crusade Prayer (33)
Seal of the Living God
O My God, My loving Father, I accept with love 
and gratitude Your Divine Seal of Protection. 
Your Divinity encompasses my body and soul 
for eternity.
I bow in humble thanksgiving and offer my 
deep love and loyalty to You, my Beloved 
Father.
I beg you to protect me and my loved ones with 
this special Seal and I pledge my life to Your 
service forever and ever.
I love you, dear Father. I console you in these 
times, dear Father.
I offer You the Body, Blood, Soul and Divinity of 
Your dearly beloved Son in atonement for the 
sins of the world and for the salvation of all 
Your children. Amen.
author: Tool of GOD

text:
Many people say that discovering that he died soon after is depressing. I think they have not understood anything. Death does not come to you from having a disease, we are all exposed to it at all times. We feel sorry for those who leave as if we were immortal, as if we had some kind of agreement with death so that these things only happen to others.
This boy lived more life with 17 years than many people throughout his long life. He faced very important issues when he was only a child, not only aspects of health or illness, but also issues such as acceptance and social rejection, self-esteem and overcoming mental illnesses such as depression or anxiety until he could say fully I felt happy. I don't know anyone except him and the Dalai Lama (with a life much easier than Sam's) who is able to say that for real, without objections, without fear, without feeling guilty. I don't know anyone who says he is fully happy with his imperfect life.
Do not feel sorry.
Learn
author: nerium oleander

text:
Mucha gente dice que descubrir que muri√≥ al poco tiempo es deprimente. Creo que no han entendido nada. La muerte no te llega por tener una enfermedad, todos estamos expuestos a ella en todo momento. Sentimos pena de los que se van como si nosotros fuesemos inmortales, como si tuviesemos alg√∫n tipo de acuerdo con la muerte para que esas cosas solo le pasen a otros. 
Este chico vivi√≥ m√°s vida con 17 a√±os que muchas personas a lo largo de toda su larga vida. Se enfrent√≥ a cuestiones muy importantes cuando s√≥lo era un ni√±o, no s√≥lo a aspectos de salud o enfermedad, tambi√©n a cuestiones como aceptaci√≥n y rechazo social, autoestima y superaci√≥n de enfermedades mentales como la depresi√≥n o la ansiedad hasta poder decir a pleno pulm√≥n que se sent√≠a feliz. No conozco a nadie excepto a √©l y al Dalai Lama (con una vida mucho m√°s f√°cil que la de Sam) que sea capaz de decir eso de verdad, sin objeciones, sin miedo, sin sentirse culpable. No conozco a nadie que diga que es plenamente feliz con su vida imperfecta.
No sientan pena.
Aprendan.

David also had progeria but he also sported the same self confidence that this young man, Sam, had. Despite his disadvantage (if one could even call it that) he continued to look forward, not backward. He was absolutely fearless. I am glad that I was able to call him a friend at least for a short time. God bless David and God bless Sam. Two true examples of courage.

text: This is a lovely man, I have Schizophrenia or PTSD and yet I am sure Sam's struggles were harder than mine are. But he left a legacy that this video helps me see for myself. I want to leave an imprint on people that I was a survivor of my illness and not disabled by it. It truly is painful to think he died shortly after this. I pray for his family and I hope we all look to find the weaker ones around us, not to judge them weaker, but that look in someones eyes that they are nervous or depressed and go and be their friend. I love my family, and could not have become a survivor without them and my other support team members. God bless Sam Berns.

text:
I had the great pleasure of meeting this amazing boy and his family when he was super little, probably 9 months or so.  
I nannied for him on and off when I was in my first year of college, and knew about his condition then, but life caught up with me and I eventually lost touch with the family.  
He was a special child - extremely talented even very young.  
He loved playing his pee no (piano) and was the first baby to teach me "eye-be-row" which, if you don't know,  was his version of butterfly kisses (eyelash to eyelash). 
When I learned of his passing, I was deeply saddened.  
And When I saw Tim Ferris' 5-bullet Friday on the 31st of May with the link to this video, I immediately was brought back to that time in my earlier life and just took a huge sigh. We should all be grateful for all we have and take Sam's words to heart.

The mind's the standard of the man.

text: To the person reading this comment. I wish you the best life you can ever imagine. I hope 2019 will be good for you. I know you've been struggling. I know things have been hard for you. I can relate to that a lot. But just don't give up. You are a wonderful human being. You're beautiful on the inside and outside. Don't listen to people who want to bring you down. Those selfish people who want to steal your light. Don't let anyone tell you that you are not enough. You are precious to this world. You are special. Irreplaceable. Cherish your life and the people around you that love you. Even if you think that you are alone now. You may often feel lonely. But know that you're never alone. You might've not been born with the best looks or money. But the true beauty of yours is hidden inside of your heart. Your heart that might've been broken a lot, but you're still here. Don't give up. Hold on to your dreams. One day you might achieve them. Just believe in yourself. You deserve the best in the world. You deserve happiness, love, kindness, loyalty and honesty. And I'd give you all that, to every one of you if I could. Even though you're a complete stranger, you deserve to be happy. Anyway, I'll end this comment here.

One time, when I was walking in the "Brique da Reden√ß√£o"*, passed by me a couple with it's childrens. It was two girls holding hands. I guess that the "normal" one didn't had more than 7~8 years and the other looked like him, so I can just presume that it was the same syndrome. The image of the two girls holding hands like that felt so powerful that I still don't have words for that. It was one of the few moments where I could see what is happiness right in front of me.


* = a place where many people sell used things in the middle of street in Porto Alegre, RS (Brazil)

text: Drawing inspiration from someone so beautiful, so young and perceptive, and exceptionally intelligent is what should be what drawn from this video. Instead, there are those who would think that happiness or positive thinking has little merit. They are pragmatists in the most negative of ways. I think that those who protest... completely miss the point. They might believe in learning but not about learning the self through introspection in any deep and soul finding way. The point of Sam's talk - to me at least - is perseverance against great odds, and still finding genuine happiness in a life of constant struggle. One can take away so much from him if they were truly willing to open their hearts and minds to his message!  Those who have never had to truly struggle are usually the first to point-fingers and judge. The 10k thumbs down represent those people in society who are completely lost, unlike Sam. Sam's life was one of constant struggle and yet he was able to overcome those struggles though an incredibly positive and brave disposition! In my opinion, 10k downvotes for this video represents a huge sickness within society and those with that sickness have decided to embrace that disease rather than rising above it, like Sam was committed to doing and trying to teach us.

text:
I don't see this as a weakness... I truly believe it is more of a personal challenge than a burden and I know that what I'd just said sounds contradictory in part, but we're born not with a predisposition but with a "blueprint" where most of what we need to overcome is included and planned by ourselves. Sam had this malfunction in his genes, others have negative views in life, depression, health challenges, poverty, social injustice or are simply born into a society or a country where human values are rarely appreciated never mind human life. I don't see him as a "rarity" although medically he is, the challenges of the human spirit run much deeper than we all know.
I see him as a transitional soul in need of the experience he seeks as a sentient being, as an energy source of mere intention and Value Fulfillment in which he needed only a few years before his essence moved to a better playing field of existence and this experience was needed in order to understand this next field and it's values. I don't feel sorry or even pity for his condition, I do consider it extreme but that was his decision before he was born. Most people won't understand my vision of the matter because they don't understand the Universal complexity of the human Entity or soul as it is generally known or called. I do. Other entities choose as well other extreme measures and live by it the same though we're not aware of their existence. When an Entity doesn't understand the difference between pity and True Compassion or the gap between empathy and cruelty that some humans display, specially in war conditions or victimizing circumstances, the basic expression and understanding of learning to close these gaps in the consciousness of some individuals, then the need for experience due in some people come into play. Every human choosing the cycle of Reincarnation has to go thru all the different facets of Being in a physical state and include the need to experience life as a male and female, father and mother, brother and sister, stranger and friend, giver and taker and every facet in between in order to rise above the lessons that life has to offer to ascend to a new level of understanding. So I admire beings like Sam that have the courage to risk well being for a life rich in Value Fulfillment and the connections needed to be made through Family, friends, the occasional and the familiar and evaluate every sentiment and feeling he had to endure in order to move forward to a Richer, more satisfying and plenum platform in the realm of the human soul. Happy Trails Sam. Good Job.

It might seem like what I wrote above might‚Äôve killed your beautiful vibe here but no matter what happens, the truth does not change for anyone, people change for the truth. Those who don‚Äôt..... well I guess you‚Äôll know what happens regardless of whether or not you believe what I‚Äôm saying.

text:
"Don't judge them by their outlooks, we have to look INSIDE" 
But I'm so sad that many people don't, but He is not afraid of his out looking, and just look inside of people.
I just want to be like him, someone who judge by their inside feelings.
Sometimes, I looked myself and think that why I'm not smarter than anyone and why I'm not prettier than my friends.
But after I watched this video, I felt sad for him that I have a healthy body because he doesn't. 
But I was so happy that he was keeping going forward even though he's out looking is different than normal people,
I learned a lot of important things from him and I'm looking forward to myself. 
And I also know that I don't have to be smarter and prettier.
Because there are precious things inside of my heart, there are things that no one else has.
But it doesn't mean that being brave is easy, that's why he is an amazing and bravest person ever I know. 
People know that he has already died, but he still living inside of my heart.

I hope many people learned that every single person is special, and there is nothing you can't do it.

¬†Thank you, I learned a lot of things from this video.

text: This is the sign of a true leader! Know what you can do and can't do - simple but profound. Sam Berns is a remarkable young man! Your perspective brings us great encouragement. You are a person of high quality. See each other for who we are on the inside. Provide a positive influence and have others provide a positive influence. The community can make a significant positive impact. Keep moving forward. Don't look back. Strive for the things ahead, a forward-thinking state of mind. Acknowledge troubles but move past them. I believe I can change the world. Being brave isn't supposed to be easy, but sometimes you just need to make that decision. Never miss a party if you can help it. God bless you and your family Sam.x

text:
Why do humans judge? we take only 0.07 seconds to judge but we take so long to consider other people's feelings? Clearly, we can see that he's normal in an abnormal world. He has progeria but didn't let it stop him. We can be as happy as him but the demands we want from others is the reason for the difference between us and him. We should take time to just sit in a clear open field, breathe in the fresh air and cherish what we have, consider how others feel.

Recently, my school had a satellite partnership with a school where the students have impairments ( I mean no offense to anyone by making this statement). And to see so many people judging the students with impairments, even the most compassionate seniors I know, really makes me wonder why we can't simply put ourselves in the shoes of others. Is it really so hard? THEY (referring to the impaired students) are humans just like us. But did we ever take the time to look and see how much they're enjoying themselves, by being themselves? We can be completely happy, just by being ourselves, being unique in our own way.

So please please please please everyone just take some time to sit down, be grateful, be kind.

text: Straight outta Foxboro, Massachusetts-17yr old Sam!                       And I was crying the other day about not having nieces/nephews to give my love & time to, but I think I have it pretty great after watching this. Knowing your going to die shortly and still remaining this positive, yikes.  Where I work,  51% of us suffer a disability--some as obvious as coworkers in wheelchairs,  blindness, no arms; some as unseen and as stigmatized as Mental Health diseases of the mind, and the other 49% of us have awareness and sensitivity!  It makes me wonder where I'd be if my own demons didn't get the better of me so many times (I've had amazing job offers retracted).  But watching this inspiring kid makes me promise to not be negative!!!  How very Nick Vujicic!   Must watch the "life According to Sam" documentary.  Sadly he died 1 month after this Ted Talk but his inspiration lives on!!  "I see no disease here, I see a dude with a really awesome mentality on life in the face of physical limitations!"

text:
Great philosophy. Enjoy today, every day; for we all live in the perpetual here and now. Yesterday is the memory bank we use to keep from making the same mistakes over.
Tomorrow is a promise of better things; goals set to motivate us.
But the Present is what we have, what we can change, and is ultimately all we really have.
Live every moment to the fullest; and you will feel like it's forever; for, every moment is an eternity in its own right.




.

text: My lord, I wanted to come up with more than just word's about this young man! There is no reason at all to list the AMAZING thing's about him! Watching this video gives you all of that and more! Why is it that when life produces such a brightly glowing star like Sam, the world never get's to keep them very long? These gift's to mankind remind me of a shooting star streaking across the night sky, a thing of wonder and beauty so amazing they burn out much faster than the rest of us! The only thing we can do is to be grateful for the time we are allowed to treasure them in our lives!!!!! RIP Sam, thank you for gracing us with your presence !!! GONE TO SOON!!!!! text:
I watched this video when it came out in 2013. Now, over 5 years later, I still come back to it because there is one important aspect to take away from Sam:

IF HE CAN OVERCOME HIS OBSTACLES, SO CAN YOU. 

We all have moments where we feel bad. But looking at Sam constantly makes me remember how little and irrelevant my problems actually are. Thank you, Sam Berns. Thank you for making me remember how fortunate I am as a human being.

text: Progeria is a hormonal development disease.  It is an inability to produce the hormones that direct development and healing.  The cholesterol increases because the body does not utilize the cholesterol to make hormones.  It may be a lack of the ability to make pregnenolone, PREG, and that is an over the counter drug that cannot be patented because it is a precursor to 150 hormones in the body.  The drug companies do not want you to know about this drug.  Pleae do your homework on this and see if it can extend the life of such good hearted individuals as Sam.

He has made me push my scepticism to one side and as Sam said, "I keep moving forward". We all need to do that. There are times when we get down, but we do need to keep moving forward. This clip has been a turning point in my life and I am grateful for it. text: what about us? the "normal" people? i just cant play any sport because im really bad at all of them. of course, i could do it for fun, but i would love to play well on a competitive aspect. so, i couldnt. and that¬¥s an impediment for me too. or another thing. im a guitar player. i have tendonitis so i cant play my favourite guitar licks. so in that aspect, im disabled too. so, what im trying to say is that seeing this kid and thinking "oh poor guy" is just a mistake of our thoughts. we are all disabled as humans, have things that we are unable to do, and things that we can. lets try to think this guy as equal, with different capacities, like every other human on this planet.

text: Let us not miss the point in this. Even though Sam died very shortly after this was made, and may have well known that time was short for him, he didn‚Äôt give up. Despite how hopeless the situation may have seemed to most in such a position, he didn‚Äôt let that get in the way of living his life the best that he felt that he possibly could while he was here. He not only fought his battle until the very end, but more importantly he kept his hopes, and dreams as well. He used that time, and the seemingly terrible ‚Äúhand he‚Äôd been dealt‚Äù to let his light shine for others, to be/set an example, and to try his best to make a positive difference. Too many get defeated by things in this life. Even if you are not defeated, once you‚Äôve convinced yourself that you are, you‚Äôre life is over despite any truth of the contrary. ‚ÄúThis too shall pass.‚Äù Each new day is a new opportunity to live life better than the day before. It‚Äôs not what happens to us in this life that‚Äôs important. It‚Äôs how we choose to react to it that truly matters. And most certainly whether or not we learn from it, and apply it, or share/teach with it. It‚Äôs very much about taking the lemons in life that we are often handed, and rather than being sour, or bitter, making lemonade with them instead, if for no other reason than in spite of. ‚ÄúI will not be defeated!‚Äù What an outstanding little warrior Sam was. A wonderful little man with the courageof, and a heart greater than any lion. Reminds me of the story of ‚ÄúRudy‚Äù but in a much larger, and more important way of course. He could have just as easily spent his limited days here having fun. He chose instead to spend it trying to make that positive difference, inspiring others with what he‚Äôd learned from his trials. The most important thing that I can take away from Sam‚Äôs experiences is this. I‚Äôd rather have one day on this Earth trying to make it a better place, than to have 100 years here being part of the vast problems. No matter what happens we still have the choice of living or being dead while we are here. Life is such a precious gift. Although Sam has died, the spirit in which he lived will live on in the many that his life here has touched. Be the positive difference/example and/or die trying. Don‚Äôt waste the most precious thing you have here. That is time. What would you do if you knew today for certain that you only had 1 month to live? How would you spend that time? Would you give up? Would you live it up and go have fun? Would you be selfish? Or would you do with it what Sam did? Live. Love. Learn. Be appreciative. Be humble and share it. This makes life purposeful and thus such time, effort, and a life that is never wasted.

text:
hmmm I wonder if he would have died unhappy if had to live a full life. 

If he was not ill he wouldn't have gotten this attention and if he had a full life he would die and no one would have noticed in the grand scheme of things. 

I know far too many people who hate their lives, hate working the 8 to 5 shift. 
So many depressed people, so many people who just want to die. 
It seems he had it easy. Its easier to die than to live and he knew he would not live long. 

When your depressed and hold the thought in the back of your mind that at any moment you can end it all, then life gets easier. 

Now I wonder, did he have a difficult or easy life?

text:
Before this video I almost felt like I was gonna go insane; i was crying hysterically, because I felt as if my life was falling apart üòï I'm only 18 & in now realizing college is really stressful, I have to work almost everyday, all day & I no longer have a social life & Im gaining weight. Not only that but now my mother is really sick, and has a tumor that has who knows what. 
But watching this made me feel so much better, it even brought me to tears. Just like Sam said ( even my sick mom) said "don't waste time feeling bad for yourself", I now understand life throws obstacles at you that you just have to learn to over come ! 
I highly doubt anyone is gonna actually read this but if u do plz leave some good advice on how I can improve myself a little bit ;)
Thanks to anyone that reads my comment, it means a lot ‚ù§Ô∏è

text: My wife and I had the pleasure of meeting a couple of kids with this disease while were staying at a place called "Family Inn"  in Boston just after my wife had a kidney transplant . This place was meant as a place for transplant patients to stay while in the area for treatment. We got to live in the same space as these kids, one from Romania and the other from Italy. The two were in the 5 to 7 years old range. The one thing that sticks out , is that no matter how old these kids look, they are still just normal kids inside. They have the same dreams, wants and needs of any other kid. The kid from Romania fell in love with the 'dollar stores" we have in the US. The other families and ourselves took up a collection to send the boy to the dollar store for a spending spree before he went back home. You have to admire the kids , but also their parents for their devotion and care. My wife and I realized that no matter how bad you think you have it , look at how well these kids handle adversity. Sam has the wisdom of a person the age he looks like, but is a kid inside.  My wife died this past year also , hopefully her and Sam are in the arms of Jesus with their bodies restored to full health forever.

text: if we would just listen to more young people whether they have progeria or not, this would be a big step up. i made my best and lasting thoughts when i was young, now im close to 30 and i got the feeling that when youre young, maybe you do alot of stupid shit (from an outside few) but youre much closer to the real basics of life. the older you get, the more informations flooding your brain. also a lot of people just get wasted by the real life and throw away their optimistic points of view, because they get into the range of the unhappy and envious people that want you to become the same like they are. they want you inside their swamp and do the same shitt they did and experience the same lvls of intolerance and hate, that their healthy ego got buried down under. i feel sorry for everybody but im one of those. i got limitated my whole life by teachers, institutions, even by my own parents in many ways and one day my optimism was gone. i felt all the pain of not getting accepted as what you are and so i turned hateful and uncaring myself. my young ego was veeery strong and thats my biggest strenght. nobody can destroy it, even thought i feel all these bad feelings all day. i was enlightened in one of my darkest hours, that you dont have to care about the opinions of others, even if they try to limitate you in every situation. its all meaningless. these people have no power over you, as long as you dont give it to them. its the same with all the other things. the human problem is the faithful adherence in things, that turn out to be bad. but since you remember them to be good at some point, you will always stick to the idea of it. beeing human is confusing.

text:
I acknowledge that there will be bad times in our lives, but this man's understanding of them is really inspirational. He ignores what he looks like on the outside (mind you jerks in the comments calling him "Alien"), and focuses more on what else he could do than what that one setback can't; he wasn't pushed away from people in society, but they love him and accepted him as a whole. He understood that he had it, but he move right on regardless. A true soldier that I will shamelessly salute to. 

RIP man.

text: Listening to people who suffer from this kind of conditions and who still have the courage to wake up everyday and even more, stand up in a room full of people and not talk about how hard he's life is but about positivity and how happy and blessed he feels, truly makes me have hope in humanity and teaches me that happiness is optional. While reading the comments, I found out he unfortunately passed away a few months after this ted talk which makes me very sad, but as he rightly said we should focus on the good aspects of life and the things we can achieve, and although I'm a bit shocked and touched about his death, I feel lucky that I accidentally found this ted talk, because thanks to this great boy I'm feeling cheered up and thankful. So thank you Sam, you'll always be an inspiring role model.

text:
Some of the cruel comments I have read on this video reveal the people's possible sociopathy - could  be type 1 sociopaths (rarely doing anything illegal, just taking pleasure in bullying people online whom they feel are vulnerable and weak). If you feel love and compassion, it is best to know the traits of those who cannot feel these emotions. They can be the cyberbully, cheating spouse, mean boss, police officer who crosses boundaries, rejecting parent, etc.  They will know you more than you know yourself. Bullying and writing mean things about physically ill people who are dying is definitely revealing their horns.  If you love deeply, again, please check out the traits of the type 1 sociopath. It helps to understand these hurtful individuals. 

As for this video: Thank you for sharing it! Very touching! And very inspiring! :)
